contentBlocks.quote: The VP of Front-End just rejected my design system proposal. The CEO said 'products are working, this isn't a priority.' So I built it anyway.
contentBlocks.context: Fifteen months later, the CEO mandated implementation across all 7 company projects. Here's how I turned organisational resistance into strategic infrastructure.

contentBlocks.heading: From Design Chaos to Systematic Infrastructure

before.label: What I Walked Into
items: No file organisation, naming conventions, or libraries
CEO actively resistant to design systems

left.heading: The Constraints That Made This Hard

blocks.text: Zero design system references exist for JavaFX. None of the standard tools work (Supernova, Storybook, Zeroheight—all web-only). Required custom CSS transformations. And it's the company's main product, so failure wasn't an option.
Front-end developer in Japan: +8 hours ahead, limited English, no video calls, unfamiliar with Figma. Every hand-off had to be crystal clear and self-explanatory. No 'quick call to clarify' option.

blocks.html:
"Products are working. Nobody's complained. This isn't a priority."

I had conditional support from the Design Lead and strategic interest from VP of FE (who wanted templates to bypass designers). But leadership? Actively resistant.

blocks.text: Oh, and I was the sole designer on the project. Whilst building a design system from scratch, I was also designing features, doing UX research, managing stakeholders, and learning to work with developers for the first time.

contentBlocks.title: Strategic Pivot: Solve Their Problems, Not Just Mine
contentBlocks.insight: I realised early: if I built a design system that only helped designers, it would fail. In an engineer-first culture, I needed to make the engineering team's life better. That's how I'd earn buy-in.
contentBlocks.result: Built a GitHub Action that automated Figma-to-JavaFX CSS transformation. FE got autonomy, I got adoption. VP of FE became my biggest advocate.

blocks.text: 4-layer token system: Core → Semantic → Post-Semantic → Component. 864 production tokens. 6 mode sets for state management. DTCG specification-compliant.
This isn't a basic colour palette. This is enterprise-level design infrastructure with proper layering, referencing (DRY principle), and transformation pipelines.

imageFull.caption: Token architecture: Core primitives → Semantic meaning → Post-semantic edge cases → Component-specific tokens

blocks.text: Manual token delivery was killing me. VP of FE rejected my JSON proposal ('not useful for us'). So I built a custom GitHub Action:

items: Outputs organised by sections with comment headers

blocks.html: Result: FE went from waiting days for token updates to pulling instantly from Git. I went from manual token delivery hell to automated pipeline. Everyone won.
